subject: Re: Anyway to dynamically change name of test passed to formatter?
msgSnippet: Thanks for the quick reply, especially on a Saturday night! I m missing something here, since I could not integrate your code fragments into my code.  I
messageBody:
Thanks for the quick reply, especially on a Saturday night!

I'm missing something here, since I could not integrate your code
fragments into my code. I probably do not have the hierarchy of JUnit
objects and methods clear yet.

Here is my little test case, perhaps you could fit your code into it
as an example? Instead of the loop structure you indicated, for this
particular case I assume I would use two suite.addTest(...) calls.

Ah Hah! Lightbulb just lit up:

I _think_ I understand that I have to extend TestCase into a
ParameterizedTestCase, then have TestVol extend ParameterizedTestCase
instead of TestCase. In that case, I cannot fit your code fragments
into the code for TestVol directly, but must create a separate
ParameterizedTestCase.java file and then the ParameterizedTestCase
class file to be imported into TestVol.

------------------------------------------------------
import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;
import junit.textui.TestRunner;

/**
* @author tporter
*
* To change the template for this generated type comment go to
* Window>Preferences>Java>Code Generation>Code and Comments
*/
public class TestVol extends TestCase {
// test objects

public TestVol( String s ) {
super( s );
}



public void testV1() {
Vol v1 = new Vol();
v1.calcVolume(1,2,3);
assertEquals(6, v1.getVolume());
}

public void testV2() {
Vol v1 = new Vol();
v1.calcVolume(2,2,3);
assertEquals(12, v1.getVolume());
}

public static void main( String[] args ) {
TestRunner.main( new String[] { "TestVol" } );
}

}

------------------------------------------------------
